prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Because we observe 12CO(2-1) and 13CO(2-1) simultaneously, the tolerance of the setting is very limited as shown in knowledgebase on Science portal. We set the parameters so that the OT doesn?t issue any errors or warnings. The velocity bandwidth of 153km/s is needed to cover the wide spectra of strong outflow from the luminous YSOs. H30alpha and SiO(5-4) line are expected to have much wider band-width than CO lines, and we set the band width of 1875MHz with a velocity resolution of 2.5km/s for H30alpha and 1.56km/s for SiO(5-4). The choice of the band-width, 1875MHz is to increase the continuum sensitivity.

The goal angular resolution of 0.25"(0.06pc), is a key of this project to spatially resolve outflows, filaments, dense cores and so on whose typical size scale is 0.1pc. The angular resolution of our cycle1 observations is 1 with ACA, and we will combine the data taken at cycle3 with the cycle1 data. Therefore, we dont need observations with more compact arrays.

The maximum temperatures of 12CO(2-1), 13CO(2-1) and C18O(2-1) are ~50K, 20K, a few K, respectively, from our Cycle 1 N159W/E observations. The typical line width is 5-10km/s, and we would like to set the sensitivity of 0.7K at 0.5km/s resolution to investigate the velocity structure of molecular gas. Cycle 1 N159W/E observations also shows the typical continuum flux of a few mJy at 1 resolution, and the current 0.018mJy is good enough to detect the emission even if the emission is extended. H30alpha is also detected with the past observations whose sensitivity is similar. The detection of SiO(5-4) is a bit uncertain, but we expect to have strong emission in regions with strong shocks.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Our ALMA cycle1 observations toward N159, one of the most active star forming regions in the LMC, have revealed various signatures of on-going massive star formation. We have discovered young molecular outflows having age of ~10^4,yrs toward two high-luminosity YSOs, and this is the first discovery of molecular outflows in external galaxies. We also found an indication of cloud-cloud collision as a mechanism of massive-star formation; a high-mass YSO with the outflow is formed at the intersection of two filaments. The dissipation and ionization of dense gas are also observed toward some of these high-luminosity YSOs, and these features observed in the cycle1 ALMA observations are considered to be a good probe of the evolutionary status of high-mass YSOs. Here, we propose ALMA observations toward brightest 4 high-mass YSOs in N159 region at an very high angular resolution of 0.25"(0.06pc) in order to acquire deeper insights into the O star formation and their feedback on the natal gas by spatially resolving the structure.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015.1.00402.S, "Investigating the formation of high-mass stars in giant molecular clouds in the LMC", T. Onishi 2015.1.00929.S, "Sub-parsec scale structure of quiescent molecular clouds possibly pre-forming clusters", A. Kawamura
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00554.S, "Most active on-going star formation in the Local Group: Resolving filaments and cloud cores in the LMC", Y. Fukui
